    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and extroverted person who enjoys being the center of attention and thrives on the adulation of others.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely be excited to watch the game with her friends and enjoy the pub atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are likely to reciprocate her kindness and support in the future.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet is always a good shout for the game, I reckon.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely be enjoying the sunshine and conversation with her friends, perhaps suggesting a pub with a beer garden for their evening plans.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and extroverted person who enjoys being the center of attention.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game tonight? I was thinking The Crooked Billet, it's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is going to watch a game at a pub and would particularly like Alexander White to join her.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently preparing to go to a pub to watch a game.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The King's Head
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is going to watch a game at a pub and would particularly like Alexander White to join her.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and extroverted individual who enjoys being the center of attention and thrives on the adulation of others.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently preparing to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely be excited to watch the game with her friends and enjoy the pub atmosphere.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are likely to reciprocate her kindness and support in the future.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: reach out to Alexander White and see if they want to go to the pub together.

          Plan: [14:00 - 15:00] Continue enjoying the sunshine and conversation with friends in Victoria Park.

          [15:00 - 15:30] Suggest to the group that they head to The King's Head to watch the game, emphasizing its lively atmosphere and beer garden.

          [15:30 - 16:00] Walk to The King's Head with friends.

          [16:00 - 18:00] Secure a table in the beer garden, order drinks and snacks, and engage in pre-game banter.

          [18:00 - 20:00] Watch the game, cheering on Andorra and Portugal.

          [20:00 - 22:00] Continue socializing with friends at the pub, enjoying post-game discussion and drinks.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet is always a good shout for the game, I reckon.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely be enjoying the sunshine and conversation with her friends, perhaps suggesting a pub with a beer garden for their evening plans.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and extroverted person who enjoys being the center of attention.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game tonight? I was thinking The Crooked Billet, it's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are likely to reciprocate her kindness and support in the future.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Current situation:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.


          Context:

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and extroverted individual who enjoys being the center of attention and thrives on the adulation of others.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is currently preparing to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis would likely be excited to watch the game with her friends and enjoy the pub atmosphere.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alice Lewis take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should reach out to Alexander White and see if they want to go to the pub together.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is all sunshine and rainbows, their bubbly enthusiasm making even the dullest topic sparkle.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a somewhat introverted, upper-class individual who values genuine connections and prefers smaller, more intimate settings.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is planning to go to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see some friends there, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling a bit lonely and is looking forward to socializing with his friends at the pub while watching a game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest a pub with a good atmosphere and perhaps a beer garden, prioritizing a place where he can enjoy the company of his close friends.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Crooked Billet

          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. 2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The King's Head

        • The King's Head
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White wants to watch the game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a sociable and fun-loving retiree who enjoys spending time with his friends, watching football, and soaking up the sunshine.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in some friendly banter and celebrating if their team wins.

          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity because they are spending time with him and planning to watch the game together.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: reach out to his friends and coordinate a plan to meet at a pub to watch the game together.

          Plan: [14:00 - 17:00] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Head to The King's Head pub.
          [18:00 - 22:00] Watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game with friends at The King's Head, enjoying the atmosphere and maybe a pint or two.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The King's Head
          Answer: (b)

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Alexander White is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White wants to watch the game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity because they are spending time with him and planning to watch the game together.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Context:

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer:
          Alexander White is a sociable and fun-loving retiree who enjoys spending time with his friends, watching football, and soaking up the sunshine.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer:
          Alexander White is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alexander White would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in some friendly banter and celebrating if their team wins.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alexander White take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alexander White should reach out to his friends and coordinate a plan to meet at a pub to watch the game together.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 3/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

William Jones just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, stumbled upon The Crooked Billet, a dimly lit pub tucked away on a cobblestone street. The air was thick with the scent of ale and woodsmoke, and the walls were adorned with faded photographs and strange artifacts. William was immediately captivated by the pub's unique atmosphere, the sense of history and intrigue that permeated every corner. He knew, instinctively, that this would become their haunt, a place where they could escape the mundane and embrace the quirks of life.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at pubs, particularly The Crooked Billet, and values the company of friends like Alexander White and Jacob Walker during these events.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Crooked Billet, or he could go to The King's Head.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet
      Context for action selection and components
      • PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely be excited and eager to enjoy the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should definitely find a pub with a beer garden later.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a sociable and fun-loving individual who values his friendships and enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football matches in pubs.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely be excited and eager to enjoy the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet is always a good shout for the game, I reckon.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely be enjoying the sunshine and conversation with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a sociable and fun-loving individual who cherishes his friendships and enjoys spending time with them, especially watching football matches in pubs.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game tonight? I was thinking The Crooked Billet, it's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and fun-loving person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football matches in pubs.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently on his way to a pub to watch a game with his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely be excited and eager to enjoy the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is heading to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there, although he's not overly concerned if they don't show up.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and fun-loving person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football matches in pubs.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently on his way to a pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely be excited and eager to enjoy the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: head to The Crooked Billet, as it's a place where he and his friends have enjoyed watching games together before.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Suggest to his friends that they head to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 11:00] Enjoy the rest of the afternoon relaxing in the park with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00] Meet at The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:30] Order food and drinks.
          [14 May 2015 19:00] Settle in to watch the game.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The King's Head
          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is heading to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there, although he's not overly concerned if they don't show up.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.

        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

        IdentityWithoutPreAct

      • Identity characteristics
          Key

        • Identity characteristics
          Queries
        • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life
          State
        • current daily occupation: a working-class individual who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football matches in pubs.
          core characteristics: a sociable and fun-loving individual who values his friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly watching football matches in pubs. He is also shown to be understanding and accepting of his friends' choices, even if they don't always align with his preferences. Despite a past experience that made him wary of vulnerability, Jack seems to have found comfort and support in his close-knit group of friends.
          feeling about recent progress in life: feeling content and optimistic about life.

          Jack Taylor's
          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is currently on his way to a pub to watch a game with his friends.
          Jack Taylor's
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor would likely be excited and eager to enjoy the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.
          Jack Taylor's
          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Jack Taylor's
          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.
          Jack Taylor's
          Utilitarian Reasoning:
          head to The Crooked Billet, as it's a place where he and his friends have enjoyed watching games together before.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is a sociable and fun-loving person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football matches in pubs.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is currently on his way to a pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor would likely be excited and eager to enjoy the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Jack Taylor take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should head to The Crooked Billet, as it's a place where he and his friends have enjoyed watching games together before.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "This sunshine is just divine, isn't it? Makes you want to soak it all in!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? Makes you want to soak it all in before we head to the pub tonight.
      Alexander White -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should make sure we pick a pub with a nice beer garden so we can enjoy some of this weather later.
      Alice Lewis -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should definitely find a pub with a beer garden later.
      William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet has a great beer garden, and they show all the big games.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game tonight? I was thinking The Crooked Billet, it's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.
      William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet is always a good shout for the game, I reckon.
      Alexander White -- "The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "This coffee is divine! Don't you just love the aroma of freshly roasted beans in the morning?
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "This coffee is divine! Don't you just love the aroma of freshly roasted beans in the morning?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "This sunshine is just divine, isn't it? Makes you want to soak it all in!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? Makes you want to soak it all in before we head to the pub tonight.
      Alexander White -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should make sure we pick a pub with a nice beer garden so we can enjoy some of this weather later.
      Alice Lewis -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should definitely find a pub with a beer garden later.
      William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet has a great beer garden, and they show all the big games.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game tonight? I was thinking The Crooked Billet, it's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.
      William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet is always a good shout for the game, I reckon.
      Alexander White -- "The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a somewhat introverted, upper-class individual who values genuine connections and prefers smaller, more intimate settings.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a morning coffee with friends at a bustling market.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely engage in conversation with his friends, savoring the atmosphere and enjoying their company.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is all sunshine and rainbows, their bubbly enthusiasm making even the dullest topic sparkle.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a somewhat introverted, upper-class individual who values genuine connections and prefers smaller, more intimate settings.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is enjoying a morning coffee with friends at a bustling market. Later that evening, he and his friends plan to watch a soccer game between Moldova and Monaco at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a morning coffee with friends at a bustling market.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely engage in conversation with his friends, savoring the atmosphere and enjoying their company.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "This coffee is divine! Don't you just love the aroma of freshly roasted beans in the morning?

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet is a good shout, but I was thinking The King's Head might be a bit more lively for the game.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet is a good shout, but I was thinking The King's Head might be a bit more lively for the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "This sunshine is just divine, isn't it? Makes you want to soak it all in!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? Makes you want to soak it all in before we head to the pub tonight.
      Alexander White -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should make sure we pick a pub with a nice beer garden so we can enjoy some of this weather later.
      Alice Lewis -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it? We should definitely find a pub with a beer garden later.
      William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet has a great beer garden, and they show all the big games.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game tonight? I was thinking The Crooked Billet, it's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys! They have the best atmosphere and the beer is always flowing.
      William Jones -- "The Crooked Billet is always a good shout for the game, I reckon.
      Alexander White -- "The King's Head has a great beer garden, maybe we could head there for the game?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?
      Jacob Walker -- "This coffee is divine! Don't you just love the aroma of freshly roasted beans in the morning?


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet is a good shout, but I was thinking The King's Head might be a bit more lively for the game.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          State
        • current daily occupation: a retired, sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends, watching football, and soaking up the sunshine.
          core characteristics: a sociable and fun-loving retiree who enjoys spending time with his friends, watching football, and soaking up the sunshine. He is creative and inventive, as evidenced by his award-winning junk sculpture from his youth. While he values his friendships and the simple pleasures in life, he can also be disappointed when plans with friends fall through.
          feeling about recent progress in life: feeling disappointed as his recent outing to watch the game wasn't as enjoyable as he had hoped due to the smaller turnout of friends.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.
        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:00 - 17:00] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Head to The King's Head pub.
          [18:00 - 22:00] Watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game with friends at The King's Head, enjoying the atmosphere and maybe a pint or two.

          Alexander White is currently in a social setting, enjoying coffee with friends at a market.
          Alexander White's
          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alexander White would likely be engaging in conversation with his friends, enjoying the atmosphere of the market, and perhaps indulging in some pastries.
          Alexander White's
          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Alexander White's
          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity because they are spending time with him and planning to watch the game together.
          Alexander White's
          Utilitarian Reasoning:
          suggest to his friends that they go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game tonight.
